In case you were wondering the origin of the word "statistics" (courtesy Wiktionary):

From German Statistik, from New Latin statisticum (“of the state”) and Italian statista (“statesman, politician”). Statistik introduced by Gottfried Achenwall (1749), originally designated the analysis of data about the state.

This video does a better job than most by emphasizing that the framework you use to answer a given question in statistics depends on the question. If you work in social sciences, for instance, your goal typically is to clarify a question so that it becomes answerable given the assets available and to recommend a course of action. The challenges are in the realm of logistics,  human resources, and general critical thinking. Most of the time the relevant statistical methods needed are pretty basic, well understood, and automated. Unfortunately, intro to statistics classes often present the student with a litany of statistical methods "as if" that magically results in effective implementation.

I like the emphasis on statistics as a tool of judgement, but not judgement itself. In the tea/milk example, you could also use a tool of chemical analysis to determine if there is a difference in chemical reaction between tea to milk compared to milk to tea, and if so, if that difference is in a range of chemicals known to be detectable by the human palate. Again, it doesn't give you an answer, but it might set some expectations and ranges of likelihood. On the other end, you could have her observed by someone trained in discerning cons/magic debunking to see if she displays tells of misdirection/manipulation. The important thing to me to understand is that there are always several methods of arriving at useful information, the more you understand about the pros and cons of the methods you use, the more useful your information will be. :^)

Please consider this as constructive feedback (and from my own perspective). I believe the presenter is not engaging enough, it is evident that she's reading a script, the examples are loose and she doesn't show being passionate about the subject (even though she might be).

The content of courses like statistics, physics, maths, chemistry, etc highly depends on who delivers the message. Unfortunately, I believe she doesn't t deliver the message correctly. I have decreased my consumption of economics and numbers crash course videos because I think they could be delivered in a more passionate manner.

Again, this is only my opinion and rather than being taken as destructive, consider it as feedback from a loyal supporter who believes things can be improved (this doesn't necessarily mean changing the person but improving her skills, maybe?).

Thanks for always focusing on creating awesome content Crash Course :)

I've read Nassim Taleb's "Dark Swan" recently and found it interesting - it's a book about uncertainty and the psychology of knowlege and decision making. It's central selling point: Statisticians (and especially economists) use Gaussian statistics (the bell curve, standard deviation) too much as most social questions are scalable: Black Swans, huge deviations form the norm that we can't predict have big impacts (think 9/11, 2008 financial crisis. The 1980 banking crisis destroyed the whole of the banks' profits IN HISTORY in a single incident).

Thought experiment: a.) The average person is 6'5" tall. What's the most likely distribution of hight? Answer: Around 6'5", with extremes more and more unlikely, as hight isn't scalable.
b.) Two people in the room have a total net income of 1 Mio USD. What's the most likely distribution of wealth? Answer: 50k USD and 950k USD. Wealth doesn't distribute around a mean, the net worth of the 2000 billionaires is 7,5 Trillion. 8 of them are richer than the world's poorest half. Wealth is scalable.
The proposed problem with most social sciences: their models often confuse b.) with a.).

I just want to mention that the solution to the Monty Hall problem is not as clear as it might seem. Yes, it's true that in normal circumstances switching door raises your probability of winning to 2/3, but in some formulations of the problem it's not said that you know beforehand that the host will give you the option of switching. Therefore, if the host wishes to deceive you, he will not give you the option to switch if you first pick the wrong door. If you will only have the option to switch if the first door you pick is the correct one then the probability of switching leading to you winning is actually 0. So there's no way to answer the Monty Hall problem without knowing the role of the host.

Fun fact - that tea and milk thing? it's actually true anyway, because the difference in taste is due to temperature differentials and the denaturing of various compounds in the milk at heat. start with cold milk and pour hot tea in, more heat is lost faster, therefor less is denatured. add cold milk to hot tea, and a small volume of milk is heated much faster and less heat is lost over-all, maintaining the reaction, denaturing more of the milk. additionally hot and cold tea also taste different in and of themselves, and this ALSO impacts the final temperature. This means that the ability to taste the difference between milk first or tea first, Is not a statistical one at all, it's a chemical one, with no probability involved.

If you don't believe me, try it yourself. and if you don't believe that hot or cold tea couldn't taste different, again try it yourself. and if you don't understand why, Consider this-- with the same glass, you can tell the difference between hot and cold water by the sound of pouring it into the glass. this is because hot and cold water have their molecules different distances apart, with more or less movement, which results in hotter water having a longer wavelength of sound IE lower pitch. Then consider the consequences for taste. Molecules having different distribution.

Although this might have been the origin story for the use of statistics, it's a very bad origin story because it was unnecessary for the problem it tried to answer. Though statistics are very VERY useful in other cases.... I just found it.... Ironic.
